description:
Deinococcus saxicola is a species of bacterium that belongs to the genus Deinococcus. It was first isolated from a granite rock sample collected in South Korea.

Deinococcus saxicola is a gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium. It exhibits a distinctive pink or red pigmentation, which is characteristic of the Deinococcus genus. The cells are typically spherical or coccoid in shape and occur singly or in pairs.

This species is known to be highly resistant to various environmental stresses, including ionizing radiation, ultraviolet radiation, and desiccation. This remarkable stress tolerance is attributed to its efficient DNA repair mechanisms and the production of carotenoid pigments that protect the cells from oxidative damage.

Deinococcus saxicola is classified as an extremophile, as it is capable of thriving in harsh environments, such as the granite rock from which it was originally isolated. It is believed to play a role in the weathering and decomposition of rock surfaces, contributing to the cycling of nutrients and the formation of soil.

The genome of Deinococcus saxicola has been sequenced, providing insights into the genetic mechanisms underlying its remarkable stress tolerance and adaptations to the rock-dwelling lifestyle.
